sn55.6:18.1: “Sir, it’s when King Pasenadi of Kosala wants to go and visit a park. We have to harness and prepare his royal elephants. Then we have to seat his dear and beloved wives on the elephants, one in front of us, and one behind.
sn55.6:18.2: Those sisters smell like a freshly opened perfume box; that’s how the royal ladies smell with makeup on.
sn55.6:18.3: The touch of those sisters is like a tuft of cotton-wool or kapok; that’s how delicate the royal ladies are.
sn55.6:18.4: Now at that time we must look after the elephants, the sisters, and ourselves.
sn55.6:18.5: But we don’t recall having a bad thought regarding those sisters.
sn55.6:18.6: This is that thing that’s even more cramped than that, and is considered as such.”

sn55.6:20.7: They live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
